## The App

```{=html}
<table style="border: none;">
  <caption style="text-align:left; caption-side:top;"> Figure 2. The App</caption>
  <tr>
  	  <td style="text-align:center"><img src="../man/figures/App_Main.jpeg" border=0 width="100%"> </img></td>
  </tr>
</table>
```
The front end of the app has been design to be minimalist but with enough information available to the user to work out what's going on. Figure 2 above shows the main area of the app that's visible on loading. When the app loads, the first simulation is run meaning that as soon as a user opens the app they are presented with a standard presentation of matched data to investigate. The full home screen of the app also contains a sidebar panel on the right with some additional information for users.

```{=html}

The four buttons under the main title each serve a different function outlined in the table below.<br>
<table style="border: none;">
  <caption style="text-align:left; caption-side:top;"> Table 2. App buttons</caption>
<tr>
	  <td style="text-align:center"><i class="fas fa-cog"></i></td>
    <td> Simulate the data and select the matching settings</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
	<td style="text-align:center"><i class="fas fa-table"></i></td> 
    <td>Look at the data and get insights</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
    <td style="text-align:center"><i class="fa fa-shuffle"></i></td>
    <td>Generate data from a random simulation with random matching settings</span></td>
<tr>
	<td style="text-align:center"><i class="fas fa-info"></i></td>
    <td>Links to information about the app (this website)</span></td>
</tr>
</table>
```
The <i class="fas fa-cog"></i> icon will open up a modal that is displayed in the following figured. It goes the user access data from four different simulations and a real dataset. I will briefly outline each of the simulations below.
